Gregory,

There are members of this group who can answer you question better than  
I can, but here is my take on it.

It is straightforward to do a kinetics simulation like the following:

---------------------------
from Cantera import *
from Cantera.Reactor import *

gas = GRI30()
time = 60.0

comp = 'CH4:1.0, O2:2, N2:7.52'
for n in range(20):
     t = 800.0 + 1.0*n
     gas.setState_TPX(t, OneAtm, comp)
     r = Reactor(gas)
     r.advance(time)
     dt = r.temperature() - t
     print t, dt
-----------------------------

This script produces the output:

800.0 1.94778629068
801.0 2.30921297753
802.0 2.7782845628
803.0 3.40626924496
804.0 4.28255966113
805.0 5.57838743464
806.0 7.66939597227
807.0 11.5803631706
808.0 21.653512821
809.0 1906.82125341
810.0 1906.09335139
811.0 1905.36548288
812.0 1904.63764766
813.0 1903.90984554
814.0 1903.1820763
815.0 1902.45433973
816.0 1901.72663562
817.0 1900.99896378
818.0 1900.27132398
819.0 1899.54371603

So GRI-3.0 predicts an ignition delay time = 60 seconds for  
stoichiometric methane/air at ~809 K, in (apparently)  excellent  
agreement with the methane autoignition temperature of 810 K. BUT this  
depends on the chosen integration time, and 60 seconds is arbitrary...  
If you choose 100 s, it ignites at T < 800 K, and if you choose 10 s,  
it doesn't ignite until T > 820 K.

I think in reality the autoignition temperature must depend on other  
factors - heat loss, radical recombination on surfaces, etc. And of  
course it also requires a good reaction mechanism for ignition in this  
temperature range. So I suspect to do it right requires a more  
sophisticated simulation than the simple zero-D kinetics simulation   
shown here.

Dave



On Wednesday, July 23, 2003, at 09:02 AM, Gregory Hackett wrote:

> Professor Goodwin,
>
> Could you suggest a way to get a mixture's autoignition temperature
> through Cantera?  I've tried a few techniques, but I am a little
> hesistant of the results' accuracy.
>
> Thank You,
>
> Gregory Hackett
